Parameters.Text:
Welcome back to MindTrails! Let's get started with practicing flexible thinking. 

Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise. 

Let's get started!

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 

0 = Most calm I could imagine being. 

10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being.

Please touch the sliding bar to select your response, or press 'More options...'

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better. 

An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to remind yourself that you studied a lot and were prepared? 

0 = Not at all - I wasn't able to think in different ways to feel better. 

10 = Completely - I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better.

OtherChoices: I didn't want/need to change my feelings

Parameters.Text:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared? 

An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won't draw attention to yourself? 

0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared. 

10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway.

OtherChoices: Nothing happened that made me anxious

Parameters.Text: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.
Please describe the situation in a few words:

Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.
Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. The screen will change automatically after 20 seconds

How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task?  

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.
How vividly did you imagine the situation?
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Buttons: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly;Very likely to turn out badly

Parameters.Text: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?

On the next screen, you will be asked to write about a possible upcoming event in your life, or something that you are worried might happen. Before pressing NEXT, please think about a situation that might happen over the next week when you will feel anxious, scared, or worried. This can be a situation that makes you anxious a lot, or something that doesn't happen a lot. 

As you think of an event, try to really see yourself in the situation. Where are you? What day of the week is it? What time is it? Who is around you? What are you doing? How do you feel?  

After you come up with your situation, please press NEXT.  

Examples could include taking a test, talking to strangers, using social media, dealing with family or friends, or whatever makes you feel anxious.
Please take a moment to write one or two sentences to describe the situation. Press next when you are ready to continue.
For the next 30 seconds, please picture yourself in this situation. When you are finished, the screen will change automatically.

Now, take the next 90 seconds to think of as many different thoughts that you could have in the situation as you can. These thoughts can be negative or positive. Be as creative as possible with all of the different thoughts you could have while you're in the situation that makes you anxious, especially thoughts that would help you feel less anxious.  

Please type each of the thoughts in the box below. You can put each thought on a new line. 

The screen will change after 90 seconds.

Great job! You predicted the future! Now, if your situation happens over the next week, you can have a lot of different thoughts come into your mind. Try to remember some of your thoughts that make you feel less anxious!
Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!

Sections.Name: Domains
Sections.Description: The domains listed here are some areas that may cause teens to feel anxious. Please select the one that you'd like to work on during today's training.

Parameters.Text:
Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: This class is so hard to keep up in, but decide to try a little harder.
I think that I may never catch on, but know that if I try, I'll be able to.
This test will go well.
My teacher will think I'm dumb if I do not do well.
I can ask for help to study for this test.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel ready to get going with studying.
I'm worried about asking for help to study, but know that it'll help me get a better grade.
I feel excited to prove myself wrong.
I am scared about failing, but know that trying is what matters.
I am worried about taking this test and failing.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I really don't want to study, but I know it will pay off on the test.
I'll study really hard and ask my teacher for help if I need to.
I don't want to tell my parents about how difficult this class is, but decide to tell them anyways.
I'll pretend to be sick on the day of the class so I don't have to take the test.
I'll ask my friends in the class questions if I don't understand something.

Parameters.Text:
You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: My teacher will tell my parents I am not doing well.
I have been trying really hard in that class.
My guardian may be upset, but that is something that I can understand.
My parents will think I need some extra help, and I am okay with that.
My guardian will be proud of me that I'm trying hard.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel happy that my guardian gets to learn about my progress.
I feel bad that I am a bit behind, but realize these things happen.
I am nervous that my guardian will be let down by my progress.
I'm feeling calm knowing that my guardian will accept me no matter what.
I feel embarrassed that my guardian will learn about my lack of progress, but decide it is best for them to know.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I take some deep breaths while my guardian is talking to my teacher.
I'll blame my grades on my teacher.
I may want to give up on math, but decide to keep trying because I need to pass this class.
I will want to get upset, but decide to keep calm when my guardian gets home.
I'll ask my guardian for advice.

Parameters.Text:
During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I wonder about all the reasons I could be so out of breath, but decide it is normal when rushing to a meeting.
I made it up those stairs really quickly.
Am I having a heart attack?
I wonder if my teacher will notice how out of breath I am, but decide it is okay if she does notice.
I am excited for the meeting.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm feeling excited now that my blood is pumping.
I'm happy I made the meeting on time.
I'm worried that there's something really wrong with me.
I feel embarrassed about being out of breath, but decide to listen to what my teacher has to say.
I'm panicking a little about whether I'm going to be ok, but remind myself that it's normal to feel out of breath after walking up a bunch of stairs.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I tell myself that I'm so nervous about this meeting that my heart is beating quickly, but remind myself that it's actually just my body's reaction to coming up the stairs quickly.
I take a few sips from my water bottle.
I take a few deep breaths.
I start looking up symptoms of a heart attack online to see if I'm dying.
I feel the urge to tell my teacher that something's really wrong with me, but remind myself that I'm actually OK.

Parameters.Text:
You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:
Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think about how many people this has probably happened to.
I think I will look sloppy in front of my friends.
I am getting a lot of stares, but it could be that they think the slushie looks good.
It feels like my friends are judging me, but decide they probably don't really care.
I think about how my parents will get a kick out of this.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm embarrassed that I have this huge stain on my white shirt, but probably no one else cares.
I'm confident my parent will be able to get the stain out.
I'm mad that I wasted my money, but know that I'll be ok.
I feel like a fool and want to say sorry.
I feel lucky I didn't drop the whole slushie.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I laugh with my friends about my spill.
I want to go home, but stay at the mall.
I stay silent the rest of the time we're shopping.
I clean up and keep shopping.
I feel like crying, but take a deep breath and keep shopping with my friends.

Parameters.Text:
You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidently drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidently drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think about how my family may be annoyed, but I can handle that.
People in my family have dropped stuff at restaurants in the past.
I think about how everyone sometimes has clumsy moments.
I have to be an embarrassment.
The waiter will be irritated, but I'll apologize and offer to help clean up.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidently drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm happy that the waiter doesn't seem to mind that much.
I'm able to stay calm.
I'm embarrassed that I dropped the glass, but know that people drop things all of the time.
I have a knot in my stomach after the whole restaurant looked at me.
I feel bad, but remind myself that I'll forget about this in a few days.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling.

You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidently drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I offer to leave extra money for the tip.
I want to never come back to the restaurant, but will say yes to coming back if my family wants to come back.
I want to cry, but decide that would not be helpful.
I offer to do extra chores at home, so money can be left to replace the glass.
I cry because I feel terrible.

Parameters.Text:
You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidently drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.

You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I bet they'll stop following me after they see what I post. But, they probably won't actually unfollow me.
I think they may not like my profile, but decide they probably won't put that much thought into it.
I think it's flattering.
They're probably making fun of my pictures.
I think they want to get to know me.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel curious about the reason they added me, but realize it is just because they wanted to.
I wonder if the add was an accident.
I feel energized by the add.
I feel worried about what they think of me, but know that I can deal with not knowing.
I feel flattered that they wanted to follow me.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I want to gossip about the add to my friends, but decide to stay modest.
I talk to my mom about how excited I am.
I add more fun pictures.
I unfollow the people that they might not like.
I want to message them and ask about the add, but decide to not put much thought into the add.

Parameters.Text:
You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Text: I'm worried about asking for help to study, but know that it'll help me get a better grade.

I am scared about failing, but know that trying is what matters.
I am worried about taking this test and failing.
I feel ready to get going with studying.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

Please take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I'll study really hard and ask my teacher for help if I need to.
I'll ask my friends in the class questions if I don't understand something.
I'll pretend to be sick on the day of the class so I don't have to take the test.
I don't want to tell my parents about how difficult this class is, but decide to tell them anyways.
I really don't want to study, but I know it will pay off on the test.

Parameters.Text:
You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:
Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone.

As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I'm glad it's gone.
I think about how it could bite me, but decide it probably won't.
I think it went back to it's home.
I think about how it could be venomous, but realize the chances of that are slim.
It's going to crawl on me!

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone. 

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm calm as I get into the shower.
I'm curious where it went.
I'm anxious about getting into the shower, but know I can overcome my fear.
I'm scared the spider will show up when I least expect it.
I'm grossed out, but remind myself that the spider probably can't hurt me.

As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I want to call someone to help me find the spider, but decide to just take my shower.
I want to spray bug spray everywhere, but decide to go about my bathroom routine.
I start to play some music.
I scream and run away.
I decide to turn the water on.

Parameters.Text:
As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I think about how everything is fine.
I think about how upset my family will be with me, but know that they will understand.
I think about how I could mention the situation to my family and all will be okay.
I think about how something bad may happen because I didn't get to check the appliances properly.
Our house is really safe, and our fire alarm would alert any neighbors if there was actually a problem.

Parameters.Text:

For the next 30 seconds, write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm miserable worrying about whether everything is off, but remind myself to focus on the present and take a deep breath.
I feel worried about the house burning down, but know that I can tolerate this feeling and it will pass.
I'm scared that our house is going to burn down.
I am satisfied that I checked the appliances that I could on my way out.
I feel calm now that I'm in the car and on my way out of town with my family.

Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I'll remember that I don't have to check all of the appliances multiple times before we leave.
I focus on everything that could go wrong because I didn't have time to check.
I want to ask my family to turn around so I can go double-check all of the appliances. But, I know that I can tolerate the feelings of anxiety and these feelings will pass.
I want to be upset about the situation, but decide to chat with my family.
I'll remember to ask for help to check the appliances in the future if I am running out of time before we need to go.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Way to go! Now you just have one training exercise left. You're going to practice coming up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors one more time, and this time the story is going to be from a different topic than the first two you just did. This is to help your brain practice this kind of thinking in lots of different types of situations.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.
You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I am getting a lot of stares, but it could be that they think the slushie looks good.
I think I will look sloppy in front of my friends.
I think about how many people this has probably happened to.
It feels like my friends are judging me, but decide they probably don't really care.
I think about how my parents will get a kick out of this.

Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm confident my parent will be able to get the stain out.
I feel lucky I didn't drop the whole slushie.
I'm mad that I wasted my money, but know that I'll be ok.
I'm embarrassed that I have this huge stain on my white shirt, but probably no one else cares.
I feel like a fool and want to say sorry.

You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I want to go home, but stay at the mall.

Parameters.Text:
You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:
Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

On the next screen, you'll see a situation that might make someone nervous, worried, scared, or anxious. Here's an example:

You're out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, "You need to come home right now."

In the text box, please write as many different thoughts that might come to your mind in that moment. You can add each thought to a new line. You'll have 60 seconds to do this. 

For this example, you might write: 
What did I do wrong? 
 My parent has something really important to tell me. 
 I'm really tired, so I'm glad to be going home. 

The screen will automatically change after 60 seconds.

Imagine yourself in the following situation. Please write as many different thoughts that might come to mind in that moment. You have 60 seconds. You can press "enter" or "return" on your keyboard between thoughts. 

You overhear some classmates talking about a party tonight that you didn't know about.
Great job practicing flexible thinking today. Remember, try to use your new flexible thinking skills before your next training session!
